exp: Homo erectus is generally credited with the first controlled use of fire around 1.5 million years ago.

subject: History
q: Which event reached its climax during the New Kingdom period of ancient Egypt?
o: The reign of Queen Hatshepsut and expansion of trade
The construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza
The invasion of Egypt by the Persians
The decline of Egyptian power under Cleopatra
exp: The New Kingdom was marked by great expansion and prosperity, exemplified by Hatshepsut.

subject: History
q: What was cuneiform?
o: A system of writing using wedge-shaped marks
A language spoken by the Sumerians
exp: Cuneiform is one of the world's earliest systems of writing, developed by the Sumerians.

subject: History
q: What is Hammurabi best known for?
exp: Hammurabi's Code is one of the most famous early legal systems.

subject: History
q: What event marked the end of the independence of Greek city-states?
o: The outbreak of the Peloponnesian War
The defeat of Greece by Alexander the Great
The death of Alexander the Great
The conquest of Greece by Philip II of Macedonia
exp: Philip II's victory at Chaeronea effectively ended the independence of the Greek city-states.

subject: History
q: What event led to the creation of the Roman Empire under Augustus?
o: The defeat of Cleopatra and Mark Antony by Octavian
The establishment of the Pax Romana
The formation of the Roman Republic
exp: Octavian's (Augustus) victory at the Battle of Actium led to the transition from Republic to Empire.

subject: History
q: What allowed the Maya to sustain their growing cities in the tropical environment?
o: Constructing raised fields to prevent flooding
Relying solely on hunting and gathering
Importing all their food through trade
exp: Raised field agriculture helped the Maya manage the swampy tropical lowlands.

subject: History
q: Which of the following technological advancements was NOT attributed to the Incas?
o: Use of cement type in stone construction
exp: The Incas are famous for dry-stone masonry (fitting stones without mortar/cement).

subject: History
q: The doctrine of the Holy Trinity was first confirmed by:
o: The Council of Constantinople in 385 A.D.
The Patriarch of Rome in 250 A.D.
The Council of Nicaea in 325 A.D.
exp: The First Council of Nicaea formulated the early consensus on the Trinity.

subject: History
q: Cushitic sub-branch includes which of the following languages?
exp: Afar is a well-known Cushitic language in Ethiopia.

subject: History
q: In the Oromo indigenous religion, who holds an important religious position similar to a high priest?
exp: The Qallu is the spiritual leader in the Oromo traditional religion.

subject: History
q: Which of the following highlights the significance of the Aksumite Kingdom between the 3rd and 7th centuries?
o: It was solely dependent on its internal trade network
It was one of the world's four great powers, alongside Rome, Persia.
It restricted maritime trade to the Red Sea region only
It was known primarily for its conflicts with Rome
exp: Aksum was recognized as a major global power during its peak.

subject: History
q: Which factor contributed to the prosperity of the Kingdom of Da’amat?
o: Its control over the Gulf of Aden
Its dominance over the land of Punt
Its strategic location for trade with South Arabia
exp: Da'amat's proximity to South Arabia facilitated rich trade and cultural exchange.

subject: History
q: Which event marked the end of the Sultanate of Shewa?
o: The invasion by the Kingdom of Damot
Constant wars with the Zagwe Kingdom
The overthrow of the Makhzumite dynasty
The establishment of the Sultanate of Ifat
exp: The Makhzumite dynasty of Shewa was eventually overthrown, leading to the rise of Ifat.

subject: History
q: What major craft did the Beta-Israel expand into different region after 1540 to support their livelihood?
exp: The Beta-Israel became famous for their skilled masonry and construction work.

subject: History
q: Which of the following was NOT a contributing factor to the decline of the Western Roman Empire?
o: The wealth of the Eastern Roman Empire
exp: The 'invention of the Turks' is historically inaccurate for the period of the Western Roman Empire's fall.

subject: History
q: What was the main reason for the creation of the College of Cardinals in 1059?
o: To oversee the land holdings of the church
To elect a pope without interference from kings or mobs
To establish new trade regulations in Christendom
To serve as an advisory council to the pope
exp: The College of Cardinals was established to ensure the independence of Papal elections.

subject: History
q: What claim did Pope Innocent III make during his reign (1198-1216)?
o: The authority of kings was higher than the church
Bishops should focus solely on spiritual matters
The clergy should have no involvement in state affairs
The word of the church was final and above any other ruler
exp: Pope Innocent III asserted that the Papacy had supreme authority over both church and secular rulers.

subject: History
q: The Muslim contributions in medicine during the Middle Ages included all of the following except:
o: The development of the science of optics
The establishment of hospitals for public health care
The creation of the first vaccines for infectious diseases
The compilation of medical knowledge in texts
exp: While they pioneered many medical fields, modern vaccines were a much later invention.

subject: History
q: Which Italian cities were predominantly involved in long-distance trade during the medieval period?
exp: Venice and Genoa were the leading maritime trade powers in the Mediterranean.

subject: History
q: Which Spanish adventurers are known for their conquests of the Aztec and Inca empires during the 16th C?
o: Ferdinand Magellan and Vasco da Gama
Juan Ponce de León and Hernando de Soto
exp: Cortes conquered the Aztecs (Mexico) and Pizarro conquered the Incas (Peru).

subject: History
q: How did John Calvin's doctrine of predestination influence the Calvinist community?
o: It emphasized the importance of individual salvation through works
It encouraged a strict moral code and hard work, with the belief that only the 'elect'
It rejected the need for church leaders or Priests
It focused on the importance of religious tolerance and coexistence
exp: Calvinism promoted the idea that hard work and moral discipline were signs of being 'elected' for salvation.

subject: History
q: What role did Isaac Newton play in the development of Enlightenment ideas?
o: He inspired philosophers to reject science
He contributed to the arts and culture for social development
He showed the power of reason in explaining the natural world
exp: Newton's laws demonstrated that the universe follows predictable, rational laws.

subject: History
q: According to classical capitalism, what role should government play in the economy?
o: Active regulation and intervention in the market
Complete control over production and wages
Limited intervention, following the principle of laissez-faire
Ensuring equal distribution of wealth among the population
exp: Laissez-faire capitalism advocates for minimal government interference in the market.

subject: History
q: How did imperialism relate to the industrial revolution?
o: Imperialism developed after the Age of Exploration, unrelated to industrialization
Imperialism was a direct result of earlier industrialization
Industrialization did not impact imperialism at all
exp: Industrialized nations sought colonies for raw materials and new markets for their goods.

subject: History
q: By 1850, which industry in Britain was dominated by the factory system?
exp: The cotton textile industry was the first to be fully transformed by the factory system.

subject: History
q: Who was invited to lead the Sicilian uprising in 1860?
exp: Giuseppe Garibaldi led the 'Red Shirts' to support the uprising in Sicily.

subject: History
q: What was one of the primary obstacles to German unification in the 1850s?
o: Austria's desire to maintain leadership in the German Confederation
The strong feeling German nationalism North and South Germany
The support of the German princes for unification
Cultural unity between North and South Germany
exp: Austria rivaled Prussia for dominance over the German states, hindering unification.

subject: History
q: What was the outcome of the American Civil War?
o: The Union was preserved, and slavery was abolished
The North agreed to a peace treaty with the South
The war ended in a stalemate
exp: The Union victory resulted in the 13th Amendment and the end of slavery.

subject: History
q: What caused Pan-Slav nationalists in Serbia to become outraged in 1908?
o: Austria-Hungary's annexation of Bosnia and Herzegovina
The dissolution of the Ottoman Empire
The creation of the Entente Cordiale
exp: The annexation of Bosnia by Austria-Hungary threatened Serbian nationalist goals.

subject: History
q: What was the Entente Cordiale of 1904?
o: An agreement between Britain and Austria-Hungary
A peace agreement between Germany and France resolving their differences
An agreement between Britain and France resolving their differences
A commercial treaty between Britain and Russia
exp: It was a series of agreements between Britain and France, ending colonial disputes.

subject: History
q: What was the primary reason the 'Legitimate Trade' replaced the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade?
o: The demand for human labor declined
The abolition of the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade by European
African rulers stopped participating in the slave trade
exp: The industrial revolution changed economic interests, leading Europeans to favor raw material trade over slaves.

subject: History
q: What was a result of the economic decline in the early 1870s for European powers?
o: Increased focus on domestic industrial development
Europeans turned to non-industrial regions like Africa
exp: Economic depression in Europe pushed powers to seek new markets and resources in Africa.

subject: History
q: Which countries were part of the territories over which Germany declared a protectorate in 1884?
exp: Bismarck declared these West and Southwest African territories as German protectorates.

subject: History
q: Where was the Wassoulou Empire located?
o: Present-day Guinea, Sierra Leone, Côte d'Ivoire
exp: Samori Toure's Wassoulou Empire was located in West Africa.

subject: History
q: What role did Samori Toure play in resisting colonialism?
o: He allied with the British to fight the French
He introduced Western military tactics to Africa
He formed a powerful empire and resisted French
He united all African states to resist colonization
exp: Samori Toure is famous for his long military resistance against French colonial expansion.

subject: History
q: What happened to Urabi after the failure of his revolt?
o: He fled to Sudan and continued his resistance
He was pardoned immediately and remained in Egypt
He was exiled to Ceylon (now Sri Lanka)
exp: Ahmed Urabi was exiled by the British after the defeat of his nationalist revolt.

subject: History
q: Who laid the foundations for the French policy of 'Direct Rule'?
exp: Albert Sarraut was a key colonial administrator who formalized the French system of governance in Africa.

subject: History
q: Which of the following was a characteristic of the Belgian administrative system in the Congo?
o: Large-scale extraction of natural resources through forced labor
Focus on education and social development
exp: King Leopold II's rule in the Congo was notorious for extreme exploitation and forced labor.

subject: History
q: The main goal of the French policy of Assimilation was:
o: To turn Africans into French citizens by adopting French language and culture
To prepare African colonies for independence
To create a separate legal system for Africans
exp: Assimilation aimed to integrate colonial subjects into French cultural and political life.

subject: History
q: Which treaty marked the formal end of the First World War?
exp: The Treaty of Versailles (1919) officially ended the war between Germany and the Allied Powers.

subject: History
q: Which of the following was NOT a major cause of World War I?
exp: The Great Depression occurred in 1929, well after World War I (1914-1918) had ended.

subject: History
q: The League of Nations was created primarily to:
o: Prevent future world conflicts through diplomacy
exp: Its main mission was to maintain world peace through collective security and negotiation.

subject: History
q: Who was the leader of the Bolshevik Revolution in Russia in 1917?
exp: Vladimir Lenin led the Bolsheviks to power, establishing the Soviet state.

subject: History
q: The 'Zemene Mesafint' (Era of Princes) in Ethiopia was characterized by:
o: The dominance of regional lords and a weak central emperor
exp: During this era, power was fragmented among regional warlords while the Emperor was a figurehead.

subject: History
q: Who was the main architect of the modern Ethiopian state during the late 19th century?
exp: Menelik II is credited with significant territorial expansion and modernization (telephones, railways, etc.).

subject: History
q: The Battle of Adwa (1896) was significant because:
o: It led to the colonization of Ethiopia
It was the first major victory of an African power over a European colonial army
It marked the beginning of the Italian occupation
exp: Adwa's victory preserved Ethiopian independence and inspired pan-Africanism globally.

subject: History
q: What was the main purpose of the Council of Kormat in 1878?
o: To discuss military strategy against the Mahdists
To resolve religious differences within the Orthodox Church
To establish a new administrative capital
exp: The Council of Boru Meda (often associated with Kormat) aimed to unify Orthodox Christian doctrine.

subject: History
q: The Hewett Treaty (1884) was signed between Ethiopia and:
exp: The treaty was between Emperor Yohannes IV and Britain (Admiral Hewett) regarding Bogos and port access.

subject: History
q: Which Italian leader came to power in 1922 and later invaded Ethiopia?
exp: Mussolini led the Fascist party and launched the second Italo-Ethiopian war in 1935.

subject: History
q: The main reason for the failure of the League of Nations to stop the Italian invasion of Ethiopia was:
o: The lack of an effective enforcement mechanism (army)
Italy had the support of the USA
The League did not recognize the invasion
exp: The League's inability to impose serious sanctions or use force made it ineffective.

subject: History
q: The 'Black Lion' organization was:
o: An Ethiopian resistance movement against the Italian occupation
A commercial company during the Menelik era
exp: It was a patriotic resistance group formed by graduates of the Holeta Military Academy.

subject: History
q: In which year was Ethiopia liberated from Italian occupation?
exp: Ethiopian patriots and Allied forces defeated the Italians in 1941.

subject: History
q: The United Nations (UN) was established in 1945 to replace which organization?
exp: The UN was founded after WWII to succeed the failed League of Nations.

subject: History
q: The Cold War was a period of tension primarily between:
o: The USA and the Soviet Union
exp: It was a global ideological and geopolitical struggle between Western and Eastern blocs.

subject: History
q: Which movement aimed to unite all African people in the struggle for independence?
exp: Pan-Africanism sought to foster solidarity among all people of African descent.

subject: History
q: The Organization of African Unity (OAU) was founded in 1963 in:
exp: Addis Ababa remains the headquarters for the OAU (now the African Union).

subject: History
q: Which event led to the downfall of the Ethiopian monarchy in 1974?
o: The popular revolution and military coup
exp: Economic hardship and political unrest led to the 1974 revolution that ousted Haile Selassie.

subject: History
q: What was the 'Derg'?
o: A committee of military officers that ruled Ethiopia after 1974
exp: The Derg was the military junta that governed Ethiopia following the revolution.

subject: History
q: The policy of 'Land to the Tiller' was implemented during which era?
exp: The 1975 land reform was a cornerstone policy of the Derg regime.

subject: History
q: Which international agreement aims to address climate change?
exp: The Paris Agreement is the current global framework for reducing carbon emissions.

subject: History
q: The term 'Globalization' refers to:
exp: Globalization involves the exchange of ideas, products, and culture across borders.

subject: History
q: A primary source in history is:
o: An eyewitness account or original document from the time of the event
exp: Primary sources (letters, diaries, artifacts) provide direct evidence from the past.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following statements is NOT CORRECT about the concept of geography?
o: Geography study both physical and human things and phenomena.
Geography is a science of argument and reason of cause and effect.
Geography emphasize on mere names of places.
exp: Modern geography goes beyond just naming places; it focuses on spatial analysis and the relationship between humans and the environment.

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following geospheres of the earth represents the solid part of the planet?
exp: The Lithosphere is the solid, outer part of the Earth, including the crust and the upper mantle.

subject: Geography
q: Which approaches of geography is used to study the spatial variations of one element on the earth’s surface?
exp: The Systematic approach studies a specific geographic element (like climate or agriculture) across the entire world or a region.

subject: Geography
q: The basis of the philosophy of environmental determinism is
o: Human beings are the master of nature and controlled the environment.
The natural environment is an influencing factor on humans’ mode of living.
Two-way relationships exist between humans and the environment.
People can influence the environment to enhance their way of life.
exp: Environmental determinism is the belief that the physical environment, especially climate and terrain, determines human culture and social development.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is TRUE about transport networks?
o: Different vehicles have different hill climbing capacities.
Roads are affected by relief much more than Railways.
Roads require much smaller gradients than Railways.
The maximum gradient for railways is 25 %.
exp: Transport networks are influenced by topography, and different modes of transport (trucks vs. cars) have varying abilities to handle steep slopes.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is a satellite-based navigation system used to capture latitude, longitude and altitude?
exp: GPS (Global Positioning System) uses satellite signals to provide precise location data including coordinates and elevation.

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following statements is characteristics of desert and semi-desert climate?
o: A well-defined rainy season of three to eight months
Low fluctuations in temperature within a day
Annual rainfall ranging between 500 and 1,500 mm
exp: Deserts are characterized by very low, irregular, and unpredictable rainfall.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is NOT CORRECT about the characteristics of research?
o: Research activities focuses on the solution of problems.
Research is employed to test hypothesis.
Research outcomes add to the existing knowledge.
Research is the dissemination of existing knowledge
exp: Research is about discovering new knowledge or verifying existing theories, not just spreading (disseminating) what is already known.

subject: Geography
q: Which one is NOT a mechanism of selecting samples in simple random sampling?
exp: Quota sampling is a non-probability sampling technique, whereas the others are probability-based (random) methods.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is NOT the characteristics of action research?
exp: Action research is flexible and cyclic, not 'fixed'. It evolves as the researcher learns from the process.

subject: Geography
q: ----is an educated guess that shows the direction where the solution to the problem lies.
exp: A hypothesis is a tentative, testable explanation or prediction in a scientific investigation.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is WRONG about acceptable hypothesis?
o: A hypothesis must have explanatory power
A hypothesis must be capable of being measured and testable
A hypothesis must be stated as simply and concisely as possible
A hypothesis must state the expected difference between variables
exp: An acceptable hypothesis usually states an expected *relationship* (not necessarily a difference) between variables.

subject: Geography
q: In which of the following probability sampling technique each unit of the population has an equal chance of being selected?
exp: Simple random sampling is the most basic probability sampling where every member has a strictly equal chance of selection.

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following non-probability sampling technique involves choosing the nearest individuals as a sample until the required sample size has been obtained?
exp: Convenience sampling (also called accidental sampling) relies on data collection from people who are most accessible or nearby.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is advantages of observation data collection instrument?
o: The data may reflect observer’s bias
Interaction between the observer and a subject
It is costly to collect data
exp: One key advantage of observation is the direct interaction or recording of behavior as it occurs in a real-life setting.

subject: Geography
q: Topographic maps that portray different features at the same time are called
exp: Topographic maps are general-purpose reference maps that show various natural and man-made features simultaneously.

subject: Geography
q: ---- are qualitative maps that use pictures and letters to show the spatial distribution of geographic element.
exp: Choroschematic maps use symbols, pictures, or letters to represent different qualitative features on a map.

subject: Geography
q: Maps that show equal rainfall distribution are known as
exp: Isohyets are lines on a map connecting points that receive the same amount of rainfall.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following is NOT properties of a globe?
o: All meridians converge at the poles
All meridians and parallels on a globe intersect at right angles
All parallels are parallel to the equator and to each other
Parallels increase in length as they approach the poles
exp: On a globe, parallels (lines of latitude) actually decrease in length as they move toward the poles.

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following maps are used to show the distribution of average values?
exp: Choropleth maps use shading or coloring to show average values (like population density) within predefined areas.

subject: Geography
q: On the given map, closer contour lines show
exp: When contour lines are close together, it indicates that the elevation changes rapidly over a short distance, signifying a steep slope.

subject: Geography
q: If the contour interval on a topo map is 10 meters, and one contour line is labeled 50 meters the adjacent contour line would represent
exp: The adjacent line would be one interval higher (50 + 10 = 60) or lower (50 - 10 = 40). Based on the options, 60 is the correct fit.

subject: Geography
q: How are streams indicated on a topographic map?
o: By contour lines that form U – shape which point upstream
By contour lines that form V – shape which point upstream
By contour lines that form U – shape which point downstream
By contour lines that form V – shape which point downstream
exp: Contour lines form a 'V' shape when crossing a valley/stream, and the tip of the 'V' always points toward higher ground (upstream).

subject: Geography
q: A scale 1:1000 on a top map indicates that
o: The map represents the entire earth
1000 unit on the map equals 1 unit in the real world
1 unit on the map equals 1000 unit in the real world
1 unit on the map is greater than 1 unit in the real world
exp: Representative Fraction (RF) scale shows the ratio where 1 unit on the map represents 1000 of the same units on the ground.

subject: Geography
q: The distance between contour lines on a topo map is called
exp: The vertical distance (elevation difference) between two successive contour lines is the contour interval.

subject: Geography
q: ---- Shows how to measure the real distance between two places on a map.
exp: Map scale is the tool used to convert measurements on a map into actual real-world distances.

subject: Geography
q: The population pyramid of Ethiopia looks like
o: triangle with a very broad base tapering to a narrow apex
indicates the preponderance of the old age population
the level of mortality is low and that very few people reach old age.
rectangular with very wide base and narrow apex
exp: Ethiopia has a young population, resulting in a broad-base pyramid (high birth rate) that thins out toward the top.

subject: Geography
q: The age structure of Ethiopia’s population indicates
o: has a high proportion of old age population
has a high proportion of young age dependent population
has a low proportion of young age dependent population
has the lowest Population of child population
exp: Like most developing nations, Ethiopia has a high youth dependency ratio due to high fertility rates.

subject: Geography
q: The population pyramid of developed countries reflects -
o: Balanced proportion of people in various ages
Shows high proportion of young people
exp: Developed countries usually have stable or declining populations with low birth/death rates, creating a more rectangular or 'top-heavy' pyramid.

subject: Geography
q: The three most sparsely populated regions of Ethiopia are
o: Harari, Afar and Beneshangul Gumuz regions
exp: Arid regions like Afar and Somali, and the remote lowlands of Gambella, have lower population densities compared to the highlands.

subject: Geography
q: Why is Ethiopia’s population distributed unevenly? Because
o: Ethiopia is the land of both Christian and Muslims
Resource use pattern of the country
Development of infrastructure within the country
exp: Population distribution is determined by a mix of physical factors (climate, soil) and human factors (history, economy).

subject: Geography
q: The very high concentration of people over the central highlands of Ethiopia is partly the result of
o: movements of the Semitic and Cushitic (Oromo) People
exp: The temperate climate (Dega/Woina Dega), fertile soil, and relative freedom from tropical diseases make the highlands attractive for settlement.

subject: Geography
q: In Ethiopia, a given settlement is said to be urban when it fulfills the following criteria Except
o: The settlement has a minimum of 2000 people.
Two-thirds of the population are engaged in non-agricultural activities
The settlement has a chartered municipality.
exp: Urban areas are defined by secondary and tertiary activities; 'primary economic activities' (like farming) are characteristic of rural areas.

subject: Geography
q: The two major historical factors beneath the development of many urban centers in Ethiopia were
o: The movement of Cush People and Ethio-Djibouti railway
Interconnection of different parts by all-weather roads and the five-year Italian occupation
The presence of raw materials and Industrial products
exp: The Italian occupation and subsequent road developments significantly spurred the growth of many Ethiopian towns.

subject: Geography
q: Permanent rural settlements of Ethiopia are associated with
exp: Sedentary (permanent) life is most common in the highlands where crop cultivation is the main stay.

subject: Geography
q: The difference between fertility and mortality is known as
exp: Rate of Natural Increase (RNI) is calculated by subtracting the death rate from the birth rate.

subject: Geography
q: Which regional state of Ethiopia has the highest fertility rate?
exp: According to demographic surveys, Afar and Somali regions often record the highest total fertility rates in the country.

subject: Geography
q: All of the following are major objectives of ADLI Except:
o: Expanding financial institutions to help improve the financial status of local farmers.
exp: ADLI (Agricultural Development Led Industrialization) focuses on all the listed agricultural improvements; 'None of this' (E) is the likely answer if all others are correct objectives.

subject: Geography
q: To which neighboring countries Ethiopia has a minor relationship
exp: Due to historical conflicts and border issues, relations with Eritrea and Somalia have historically been more strained/minor compared to others.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following mountain of Ethiopia is different from the others in its location?
exp: Chilalo, Batu, and Tulu Dimtu are in the South-Eastern Highlands (Arsi/Bale), while Gughe is in the South-Western Highlands (Gamo).

subject: Geography
q: What is metadata in GIS?
exp: Metadata provides information about the content, quality, and condition of a dataset.

subject: Geography
q: Which of these is a software component of GIS?
exp: ArcGIS is one of the most widely used software suites for geographic information systems.

subject: Geography
q: What is geospatial data primarily used for?
exp: Geospatial data is used to visualize and analyze how things relate to one another in a specific physical space.

subject: Geography
q: Identify the correct chronological order
exp: The supercontinent Pangea first split into Laurasia and Gondwanaland. Then Gondwanaland broke apart, eventually separating Africa before Madagascar became an island.

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following Era is responsible for the formation of the present surface configuration of the African continent?
exp: The Cenozoic Era, particularly through volcanic activity and the formation of the Rift Valley, shaped much of Africa's current topography.

subject: Geography
q: The Great East African Rift Valley was formed as a result of:
exp: The Rift Valley is a classic example of a landform created by large-scale faulting and the pulling apart of tectonic plates.

subject: Geography
q: Which one of the following controls of climate affects the amount of incoming solar radiation a place receives?
exp: Latitude determines the angle of the sun's rays, which directly controls the intensity and amount of solar radiation received.

subject: Geography
q: The Atlas and Cape Ranges have the lowest temperature in the continent as a result of
o: Their short distance from the sea
Their high altitudinal and latitudinal location
exp: These ranges are located at the extreme northern and southern tips of Africa (high latitude) and have significant elevation (altitude), both of which lower temperature.

subject: Geography
q: Which part of Africa has equatorial type of climate?
exp: Central Africa, particularly the Congo Basin, lies along the equator and experiences high temperatures and rainfall year-round.

subject: Geography
q: Which is NOT an example of soil conservation in Ethiopia?
exp: Overgrazing is a cause of soil erosion and land degradation, while the others are methods used to protect and conserve soil.

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following represents the correct order of geologic time divisions, from largest to smallest?
exp: In geologic time, an Eon is the largest division, which is subdivided into Eras, then Periods, and finally Epochs.

subject: Geography
q: Which force drives the continental drift theory?
o: Convection currents in the earth's mantle
The expansion of the earth's crust
exp: Continental drift is primarily driven by the heat-generated convection currents in the underlying semi-fluid mantle.

subject: Geography
q: The Earth's core is primarily composed of:
exp: The inner and outer cores of the Earth are mostly made of heavy metals, specifically iron (Fe) and nickel (Ni).

subject: Geography
q: Which of the following is NOT a major element of weather and climate?
exp: Temperature, rainfall, and humidity are atmospheric conditions (elements of weather), whereas soil type is a terrestrial characteristic.

subject: Geography
q: Monsoon winds are caused by:
o: Differences in air pressure over land and sea
exp: Monsoons are seasonal winds caused by the differential heating of land and water, creating distinct pressure differences.

subject: Geography
q: The rain shadow effect is most closely associated with:
exp: Orographic rainfall occurs when mountains block moisture; the side facing the wind gets rain, while the other side remains dry in a 'rain shadow'.

subject: Geography
q: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is associated with:
exp: The ITCZ is the area near the equator where trade winds meet, characterized by consistent low pressure and heavy precipitation.

subject: English
q: Which of the following is the correct word order? (parents / after / of / your / you / which / take / do?)
o: which of you do take after your parents?
Which of your parents you do take after?
Do you take which of your parents after?
Which of your parents do you take after?
exp: 'Take after' is a phrasal verb, and in a question format, the auxiliary 'do' comes before the subject.

subject: English
q: Which sentence is correctly ordered? (Were / the / is / that / it / about / time / presentation / on / the)
o: She is on about time that it were the presentation.
It is the presentation that she were on about time.
She is on about time that were it the presentation.
It is about time that she were on the presentation
exp: The structure 'It is about time' is followed by a subject and a past subjunctive verb.

subject: English
q: Which sentence is correctly ordered? (or / play / tennis / would / like / you / afternoon / this / not?)
o: Would you like or not to play tennis this afternoon?
Would you like to play tennis this afternoon or not?
Would you like play tennis or this afternoon not to?
Would you play tennis like this afternoon or not to?
exp: The standard polite invitation structure is 'Would you like to [verb]... or not?'

subject: English
q: Which sentence is correctly ordered? (.he / no / knows / why / doesn’t / one / come)
o: No one doesn’t knows why he come.
No one knows why he doesn’t come.
Why doesn’t he come no one knows.
Doesn’t one knows why he no come.
exp: The subject 'No one' is singular and takes 'knows', followed by a noun clause.

subject: English
q: Correct word order: (did / say / I / I / not / that / anything / so / was / surprised)
o: I was not so surprised that I did say anything.
I did say that anything I was not so surprised.
I was so surprised that I didn’t say anything.
I didn’t say anything I was so surprised that.
exp: The structure 'so [adjective] that [result]' is used here correctly.

subject: English
q: Rearrange to form a coherent paragraph: (a. One day he met a beautiful girl, b. He took money from rich, c. Robin Hood is a hero, d. Her father wanted to marry her to a rich man, e. He lived in the 12th century)
exp: The logic starts with the introduction (c), the time period (e), his action (b), the meeting (a), and the conflict (d).

subject: English
q: Lucy says she bought her new trousers suit in __________.
exp: 'In a sale' is the standard idiomatic expression for buying clothes at a discounted price.

subject: English
q: According to Charles Darwin, man is __________ from the apes.
exp: In biological terms regarding ancestry, 'descended from' is the correct term.

subject: English
q: We’ll have to __________ the meeting until next week because no one can come tomorrow.
exp: 'Put off' is a phrasal verb meaning to postpone or delay.

subject: English
q: __________ if Aster should find her purse.
o: She’d never be careless about her possessions again.
She’ll never be careless about her possessions again.
She’d never been careless about her possessions again.
She ‘d never had been careless about her possessions again.
exp: This is a conditional sentence. 'Should' in the if-clause suggests a future possibility, paired with 'would'.

subject: English
q: Her principal occupation was finding enough to eat. What is the function of the underlined gerund (finding)?
exp: It follows a linking verb ('was') and describes the subject, making it a subject complement.

subject: English
q: The more distant a star happens to be, __________ to us.
exp: The double comparative structure: 'The [comparative]..., the [comparative]...'.

subject: English
q: I clearly remember __________ it by the window and now it has gone.
exp: Remember + gerund refers to a past action (the act of putting it there).

subject: English
q: Which one is odd in pronouncing of the -s ending?
exp: Brushes, catches, and cages end in /iz/, while 'baths' ends in /s/ or /z/ depending on dialect, but lacks the extra syllable /iz/.

subject: English
q: Which of the following is the correct word order? (parents after of your you which take do?)
o: which of you do take after your parents?
Which of your parents you do take after?
Do you take which of your parents after?
Which of your parents do you take after?
exp: The correct question structure is 'Which of [noun] + auxiliary + subject + verb?'

subject: English
q: Which sentence is correctly ordered? (Were the is that it about time presentation on the)
o: She is on about time that it were the presentation.
It is the presentation that she were on about time.
She is on about time that were it the presentation.
It is about time that she were on the presentation
exp: 'It is about time' is followed by the past subjunctive.

subject: English
q: Rearrange: (a. One day he met a beautiful girl, b. He took money from rich, c. Robin Hood is a hero, d. Her father wanted to marry her to a rich man, e. He lived in the 12th century)
exp: Intro (c) -> Time (e) -> Action (b) -> Meeting (a) -> Conflict (d).

subject: English
q: A little boy showed his father pen-knife. (a. little boy..., b. 'Are you sure it was lost?', c. 'I saw a man...', d. He said he had found it...)
exp: The boy shows the knife (a), says he found it (d), father asks if it was lost (b), boy confirms (e).

subject: English
q: Lucy says she bought her new trousers suit in __________.
exp: 'On sale' or 'in a sale' is the standard phrase for discounted shopping.

subject: English
q: The lighted candles on the altar __________ in the draught from the window.
exp: Flame 'flickers' when there is a light wind.

subject: English
q: Being already a graduate from another university, he was ___________ from the entrance examination.
exp: 'Exempted' means being free from a requirement others must follow.

subject: English
q: Man: We missed you at Mike's party last night. Woman: I was badly engaged elsewhere. Moreover, I can’t tolerate Mike any more. What does the woman mean?
o: She was too fond of Mike.
She had another appointment and she wished to avoid Mike.
exp: 'Badly engaged' means she had other plans, and 'can't tolerate' means she wanted to avoid him.

subject: English
q: Which one of the following sentences is correctly punctuated?
o: What do you mean when you say “hyphenation?”
What do you mean when you say “hyphenation”?
What do you mean when you say, “hyphenation”?
What do you mean when you say, “hyphenation”?
exp: The question mark belongs to the whole sentence, so it goes outside the quotation marks of a single word.

subject: English
q: “Previous experience as a security guard would be an advantage.” This statement is likely taken from a ____________.
exp: Job requirements are typically found in job advertisements.

subject: English
q: The most appropriate closing for a letter to your old college mate is ___________.
exp: For an informal/friendly letter, 'Bye for now' is the most appropriate among the options.
